149572371.review:
[h1]Obra de culto muy importante.[/h1]
[hr][/hr]
Yume Nikki es un juego indie desarrollado por Kikiyama, quizá uno de los autores de videojuegos más desconocidos y extraños que hay en la escena. Este es el punto crucial que le dió un nuevo en enfoque a los indie horror rpg games venideros, tales cómo IB, Mad Father, Omori, Paranormal Syndrome etc etc. Marcando estructuras muy fuertes tales cómo el guion enrevesado con cuestiones psicológicas y simbólicas, el gameplay, el estilo artístico, tener a un/a prota misterioso/a hasta cierto punto de la trama en que se desvela entre otros.

También fue importante para marcar tendencias o modas fuera de los juegos en sí. ¿Alguien recuerda el Dream Core o Weird Core? Bueno, de alguna manera eso viene desde este título, Yume Nikki tiene un estilo artístico surreal, onírico, fantasioso, y casi repugnante en ocasiones, de manera no intencional. Algo que es difícil de olvidar como una horrible pesadilla.

[h2]Llegando a la cuestión principal ¿Vale la pena probar este juego?[/h2]
[hr][/hr]
Totalmente, recomiendo mucho subir al todo el volumen, pantalla completa, luces apagadas y no mirar una guía a menos que te empieza a estresar demás. Con todo esto es el combo perfecto para las sensaciones que transmite, es muy probable que al finalizar la aventura no entendás casi nada de lo que pasa en este extraño mundo, y ahí es donde entra el fandom que intenta explicar de todo. A pesar de tener casi 20 años este juego es tan influyente cómo otros, pero esta vez desde las sombras.
[h1]10/10[/h1]

This is one of my favorite games, it's great for when I need to unwind and need to turn my brain off for a bit.

It does take a lot of patience to play though, but I actually kind of like that. Having no sense of direction and just collecting random effects while wandering mindlessly around in a dream is so surreal in a good way. If you like horror and atmospheric games, you might enjoy this.

The game itself is pretty mysterious, you play as a girl who just dreams her days away and wanders through different worlds and doors in her dreams. No direct story or even dialogue at all. That's something i like about this game, it's so open ended and is up for interpretation about the whole story.

9/10, an unsettling but strangely comforting and nostalgic game in my opinion.

145833032.review:
I know how it feels to be scared of other people. To be scared of the outside world. The minute you step outside your door, you have forfeited control. Anything can happen to you, and everyone is watching. If something bad should happen to you, it is your fault. You could've just stayed inside. In there, no one can hurt you, because there's no one in there at all.

There are many works of fiction that detail the crushing, inescapable feelings of social anxiety and depression, but I think Yume Nikki captures it better than anything else I've encountered. All you do in this game is explore these vast stretches of creepy emptiness that loop endlessly. You don't gain or learn anything from the experience, and you give up trying to make sense of it. The music also loops endlessly, so you just become lost in these uncomfortable dark places. And yet, there is comfort. Comfort in the fact that you can't ever "lose" in Yume Nikki, and that you can immediately escape any dream world if it becomes too oppressive. That is the true nastiness of depression, that it becomes seductive in its "safe" darkness and loneliness, and you can forget there was ever any other way of existing. Yume Nikki is about a feeling that I believe everyone experiences at one point in their lives, and I find it so fascinating that an entire game was made around just this.

I've played through this game about 10 years or so ago on PC.

Yume Nikki isn't a game that is going to wow you, but it is a pretty relaxing exploration/puzzle game. There ins't action, or gunfire, or anything like that. But it is still really fun to play and look around.

The game is also kind of a trip, so if that is not your thing then steer clear. It is very old school 16 bit type feel, so if that is not your thing...this game won't change your mind. And it isn't something you will probably sit down and play for hours. It is more a game to pick up and play for a little bit at a time...get lost...and then move to something else.

But I think knowing that and going into it with the right mindset really makes this game shine. I loved Yume Nikki way back when I played it...and it is awesome to add it here. Now I can pop it on the Deck when I feel like doing some trippy exploration.

144304993.review:
The reviews don't lie, this really is not for everyone, I wouldn't call it "fun". It's the ultimate walking simulator, you're guaranteed to get lost, there's no dialogue, it can be boring when you aren't finding anything new, and you need to be patient. That said, between the art, the worlds, the music, the characters, I've found no other game that can replicate the absurdity of a dream better than this one.

You could spend time interpreting the dreams (in the same way your own dreams might be inspired by the real world), and I DO like certain theories that have floated around the internet about the meaning behind these dreams... but who's to say about any of that?

There IS an official ending to the game, so this is something you CAN "complete", but you are almost guaranteed to need a walkthrough. That doesn't include all of the optional events and interactions you might come across. There are a couple of locations and events in this game that genuinely terrified me or made me feel a certain type of way.

One more thing: The game starts slow and the default walking speed is likely too slow for most people. Luckily, there is an effect in the game that grants you a faster traveling speed and is something I recommend finding when you can. But if you want to play Yume Nikki: X-TREME MODE, then go right ahead and just walk the entire time, I dare you.

In short, this is a good game to play late at night and is the best video game representation I've seen of what the world of dreams can be like, but it's not for everyone. Luckily, the game is free on Steam, so you may as well try it out.

143759497.review:
td;dr: Surreal and perfectly unnerving game. I would recommend just starting to play the game rather than looking around too much. By playing the game, you will know what it's all about. This game would've been slightly better for me had I not looked around slightly too much.

Actual Review:
Actual fever dreams I tell you, in a really good way. I'd highly recommend this game to the adventurous type who also likes mysteries, theorizing, psychology, and diving into more mentally disturbing topics. It'd be hard to explain in a review, but imagine a mentally destroyed beyond repaired Japanese girl's nightmares that reflect her life as something you explore in a video game. And bam, you have Yume Nikki.

As soon as I entered my first door, Forest World, and traversed the inner dream worlds, I knew I was in for an extremely wild ride that hits close to home with how dreams feel, because there is literally no determining where you'll be next, yet everything seems to naturally just make sense over time. I encourage you not to use a wiki for the effects until you've explored every world and inner world you know of. I emphasize the exploration aspect of this game. There's a lot of crazy stuff in this game, some that you likely will not even see if you go for just beating the game.

Furthermore, this game inspired the creation of other video games that follow a similar premise of setting an atmosphere and aesthetics, such as Doki Doki Literature Club, Undertale, OMORI, and probably many more well known video games that hit you in the feels in this very bizarre way that I probably wouldn't be able to explain very well. Feel free to do your own research. ;)

If all this sounds like something you like, please go ahead and play Yume Nikki. :D


Warning (of Salt): If you make it to White Desert B in the extremely convoluted way, do not take the tunnel exit immediately. That exit is a one-way exit to White Desert A, so only leave when you're done. Take everything in as what you have done is not all that easy. There was no warning, and so I didn't stay there for as long as I ideally would've wanted to.

143556895.review:
If you haven't heard of this game before you most likely don't know what your getting yourself into, then again if you know a bit about the game then the same may apply. 

This game is a proto-walking simulator but I will say don't let that discourage you from checking it out as while the game play can prove to be tedious at times with walking down near endless hallways and looping maps, the scenery is beautiful, mystical, and unique and leaves a lot to interpret. Along with having a minimalist soundtrack (most songs being a couple notes long) that helps to establish an atmosphere that feels like walking through ones' dreams.

This game is very much akin to its predecessor, LSD Dream Emulator, whereas the game is not something you play to win or complete but rather to experience, kinda like looking at a painting.

For anyone hoping to start the game, I heavily encourage not playing just to get all the effects and get to the ending, but to rather to simply explore and enjoy the visuals and events present through the game.

If you are looking for a game where the goal is to complete and go through the story to end, then you may want to check out the 2018 remake of Yume Nikki, Yume Nikki: Dream Diary. However, I prefer the original as it simply is much of a better experience and does exactly what it is supposed to for a game of its calibre.

142427702.review:
I, unfortunately, do not have the personal experience or connection to this game as many other people do. I knew about Yume Nikki growing up, but I was never really *into* whatever it was trying to do.

But revisiting this game as a young adult definitely made me appreciate this game a lot more. I quickly realized that the "objective" of the game isn't to get every effect. Those are closer to easter eggs than a "goal", per se. This game is more about the feelings it evokes on the player as you wander around the surreal spaces inside of Madotsuki's dreams. Feelings of loneliness, sadness, dread and insecurity.

With how "weird" the game is, there are, actually, common themes in the places you visit, if you pay enough attention. A common thread that, while difuse, gives you the pieces you need to understand what Madotsuki is going through, and what afflicts her mind.

This is a great game, for the people that it's meant for.
It requires a lot of patience (especially if you don't have the Effect which increases your movement speed), a very good memory for where you have and haven't been (unless you don't mind wasting time going back over territory you've already seen), and a lot of time. It didn't take me too long to realize the game's environments were way too vast for me to attempt exploring on my own while keeping my sanity, so I found a walkthrough to take me through the Effects so I could see the game's conclusion.
Before playing, I read a primer for new players which said that there was no 'winning' or 'losing' Yume Nikki, and I think they were right. I've gotten into some experimental games, but personally I think this required a bit too much time and patience with too little direction for me to appreciate. In fairness, I probably should've taken the game's own description to heart and given this one a miss.
That said, if the description of the game [i]does[/i] pique your interest, by all means don't let me dissuade you.

138305227.review:
Yume Nikki is a atmopheric, creepy but interessting game made in 2004 by Kikiyama. In the game you play as a girl whose name is 'Madotsuki'. After she goes to sleep you follow along on her journey through a lot of weird worlds and locations in her dreams. You will meet a lot of strange characters and in each world you can collect different items/effects such as umbrellas, Knives and anything in between by interacting with things or creatures. The game contains some horror elements and a massive amount of creativity and weirdness. 

The game is a walking and exploration RPG Maker game that takes about 5-6 hours per run (atleast thats how much time it took me, maybe I am just incredibly slow). However, the game does not contain any jumpscares, but some fun and creepy locations. The game is not having any specific plot and you can't communicate with any of the characters in a way of speech. The game is free as well and has an INCREDIBLE SOUNDTRACK. I can recommend this game to anyone, who likes creepy, atmospheric and creative games and it is also a good start for those, who want to start playing this kinda genre. 

One in all: Great game, good Soundtrack, Incredible Locations/Characters.
Definentaly recommend!!

(Sorry for my english, I am still learning the language)

138277360.review: The gameplay loop is simple. You explore the areas and are awarded effects for your troubles. The catch is some paths are one ways to certain places. Meaning you are rewarded for learning and remembering the layout of the map and the locations of certain paths. For some reason, I got really invested in this gameplay loop. Making a mental map, remembering where I have and haven't been, and incorporating a little bit of problem solving. There's something really rewarding and even addicting about discovering new areas, finding new effects, or even just cool landmarks. But I don't think I would find it so fun or intriguing if the art and atmosphere weren't amazing. Art's a preference thing, so I know this style won't jive with everybody. But it just does it for me, I really love the mix of calming and haunting; relaxing and unnerving.

So this game is pretty much a dream come true for me. Another thing I love about this game is how the story is pretty much entirely left up to your interpretation. I'm a huge sucker for stuff like that, and I've had a great time coming up with theories/headcanons for this game. The music is lovely, and it's very exciting to discover new places, effects, events, etc. Not even to mention the horror aspect of the game. It has a wonderfully creepy atmosphere, weird/spooky imagery, and disturbing themes that aren't too in-your-face. Playing this alone without any distractions really is quite the experience. Overall, sweet game. It's made a special place in my heart for sure.

137666169.review:
A very influential game that's worth watching videos about and analyzing, but not worth to play through. Whenever I think of rpg maker games that resonated with me, there was a gameplay that I found somewhat lacking, but a very interesting narrative that saves it. So it's all the weirder to me that yume nikki doesn't seem to get criticized for throwing both elements into the trashcan.

The gameplay is about exploring very vibrant and different dream worlds, almost all of them interconnected into a pretty cool web, if you check world map for it online, you can really appreciate the craft of it, some of the places are only accessible using specific item, so there is slight puzzle element to it too. But that's kinda it, the levels often have no interesting structure, most of the starter ones have the same concept of a dark background, sprites thrown all over it, and then all 4 borders looping the stage, the magic of such location quickly fades when you realize how little they have going for them besides the "vibe". Some levels are just labirynths with a single tileset, also quickly growing monotone. The more structured deep dreams finally start scratching that funny little thing called "sense of discovery", but the ratio of dull to interesting just isn't good enough, there is no dialogues to add to it, music is extremely short loops, and there is some unexpected image popping out at your screen every once in a while. The game appears designed to starve you for meaningful interactions, and that's precisely why some easter eggs (especially a horror one) impacted the players so much.
Naturally as there is no narrative (besides the implications of Madotsuki being a traumatized neet about to call it quits), you simply observe the variety of spritework and interpret your own meaning for them, trying to come up with more detailed backstory for the protag, as well as general symbolism for real life, that the game might be trying to do. I like wacky dreams just like the next guy, there is some subconcious art in them, but at the end it's just abstractions without anything profound to say.

The game is an experiment from all the way back in 2004, on how much of a "game" can you strip away from something, before people start calling it a "more of an experience". I am not even all that surprised about the huge amount of fan games, as all it takes to make a "world" is a single small size tileset, sprinkle sprites around, add 4 second music loop, and some doors to other worlds, and you're good to go. As long as you create an interesting atmosphere, that's all that matters for a dream diary, which is a shame, since some of these toppings are really interesting and leave me hungry for more, but they will never make a full cake.

137655149.review:
Yume Nikki and its surrounding fandom ("fandom" by which I especially mean inspired works of art) are products of a subculture of a subculture -- a specific time and place in the 2000s. It's an interactive experience, but not really much of a true "game" considering the lack of mechanical or logistical skill. It's best treated as an exploration-based or adventurist's art gallery -- a particularly sentimental one with mixed themes primarily consisting of isolation, nostalgia, tranquility, surrealism, anxiety, and mortality.

[b]If you are most looking to experience it for the first time, you [i]WILL[/i] need help to complete it.[/b] I would most recommend a tour guide (you can play it with other people in real time at [url=ynoproject.net]ynoproject.net[/url]) as to avoid spoiling yourself by looking things up on the wiki. That being said, exploration [i]is[/i] part of the point of the game, so please try to take in the sights and sounds and maybe let yourself wander around a bit instead of treating it like a speedrun. There are no irreversible mistakes or choices, so don't be afraid of losing anything; just make sure to save before quitting.

It's not for everyone, but it hits really damn hard for a few. I highly, highly recommend at least trying it. There's tons of intriguing history and mystery around its purpose, its development, and its creator Kikiyama, too, if that's your thing.

If you want a goal, there are collectibles called Effects, they're mostly just a little transformation for your character Madotsuki, weather it be her untying her trademarked pigtails and letting her hair flow down her back, or having her head turn into a grotesque, greyish-green skinned hand with a wide eye in it's palm, or even becoming a disembodied head. It's fun to simply get lost in the world while trying to find every Effect and maybe even find some kind of ending to the madness of this cute little hikikomori girl's dreams

136826021.review:
[THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS]
Short version:
It's a game for a niche crowd, but that niche crowd will adore it like few other things. Even those who dislike walking simulators and the like, will almost definitely still love the artistry. (Great soundtrack, creative visuals and characters, etc). It's not perfect, but the positives outweigh the flaws.

Long version:
So, artistically, this game very clearly takes a ton of inspiration from LSD Dream Emulator. If you like that game and also like the 2D overhead style, you will love this, guaranteed. It's a walking simulator themed around strange environments. Some are more normal (Dense Woods, Snow World), while others are more surreal (Windmill World, White Desert). There are quite a few visual similarities. For example a lot of the more psychedelic things remind of LSD's "downer texture". Number World is like the "kanji texture". But this is still clearly its own game. 

It is a bit more "involved" than LSD, but not by much. You collect effects which either change Madotski's appearance, or give her powers. You can kill NPCs but this is optional. You collect money by doing that, but the money only buys vending machine drinks which are also optional. The main focus is very clearly exploration. The audience for something like this is very niche, but for that niche crowd, this game ticks basically every box you could ever ask for. Tons of variation, tons of exploration, tons of weirdness, tons of darkness and light, very isolating, and tons of atmosphere. Horror elements alongside cuter elements. The soundtrack is varied, too. Most songs are short loops, but they don't feel "repetitive". These loops can be anything from electronic music, to ambient droning, to piano, and so on. 

The game isn't perfect. The most common complaint by far is that it's so difficult to figure things out without a guide. None of it is [i]intrinsic[/i] to enjoying the game - you don't need a guide to just walk around and experience the world, after all. But if you want to see the full potential of the game, a guide is basically required. Also, navigation can be... slow. The bicycle effect is essential to move faster. Also, the "Hand Eye" effect can teleport you back to the hub area. Without these, the game will be much more tedious. A gripe that's perhaps more personal, lies in the game's overall mood. A melancholy mood pervades the entire game. Even happy areas have this air of either fake happiness, or a temporary happiness soon to be ripped away. [spoiler]The game ends with Madotsuki killing herself[/spoiler] and the whole game sort of feels like a psychedelic precursor to that. LSD lacked this melancholy feeling, instead emphasizing the weirdness and the horror. Whether the depressive elements are a good addition or not, is totally subjective. But to me personally, it does weigh down my experience a little bit. Regardless, it is still an extremely enjoyable game in spite of these few flaws. If you like the idea of surreal walking simulators, your options are limited, as far as I know. Either LSD Dream Emulator; Yume Nikki; or ....... fan games that were inspired by Yume Nikki, lol.

134622043.review:
El juego esta bueno, te manda por un viaje onírico y aveces "terrorifico"(mas o menos) por el mundo de tus sueño. Niveles abstractos con objetivos medio abstractos.

Los niveles están buenos en su mayoría, hay alguna u otra cosa que hacer, aunque casi siempre son solo simples pasajes para llegar a otro nivel que funge como una "estación" a donde te lleva a X o Y nivel.

Dependiendo del nivel, la música esta buena, osea acompaña y es relajante, en otros casos parece un poco incomoda o "tenebrosa".

En general los powerups o habilidades están bien, varios son de un uso especifico pero están buenos y siempre da algo de alegría saber que ahora vas a poder llegar a un lugar que antes no podías(ahora toca averiguar a cual), aunque claro, este no es un juego que destaque por su jugabilidad, le tiro flores a los powerups pero solo porque en la medida de que el juego es simple, sus powerups también lo son.

Otra cosa positiva del juego es que prácticamente podes elegir a donde ir, obvio que en varias Zonas vas a necesitar X o Y powerup pero se nota ese libre albedrío que te dan al principio.

Diría que lo malo del juego es que es ultra críptico(mas que el Zelda 1) y no vas a saber a donde ir ni que hacer... en parte eso ayuda a la experiencia onírica y de estar en un mundo de sueños donde no tenes ni idea que chota pasa pero jugablemente hablando, si te mandas así nomas creo que ni te vas a pasar el juego. Quizás esto se solucionaba que se yo ¿con algún logro de steam que te diga MAS O MENOS que deberías hacer o donde ir para tener una pista? digo porque por ejemplo, ya que el juego no te explica nada en concreto, a mi me costo darme cuenta de como era la mecánica para despertarte y volver a tu habitación(cosa que es algo recurrente y fundamental en el recorrido).

Por último, me gustaría decir que por no saber exactamente que hacer o a donde ir, en caso de que te logres pasar el juego, lo mas probable es que te hayas dejado como 20 zonas que solo tienen el propósito de mostrarte "algo y ya está" como si fuera un "evento" o "premio visual" como por ejemplo, cuando haces que te aparezca la cara esa tipo Screamer. De estos secretos el juego tiene muchos, aunque no son coleccionables si fungen como tal. Repito esto se solucionaría con buenos logros de Steam, porque sino, es 100% seguro de que o pierdas el interés de seguir jugando por decir "Na ya está, con lo que me costo pasarme el juego, no tengo ganas de seguir explorando por si me falto algo"(Y lo mas probable es que si te falten ver muchas cosas) o que directamente te atasques en una parte y estés prácticamente obligado a buscarte una guía.

En fin, el juego te ofrece una experiencia bastante única, aunque realmente dudo que la disfrutes al 100% sin usar una guía, una lástima porque el juego es bastante corto pero bueno, al menos está gratis.

PD: ¡AGUANTE THE DOCKS! tanto en diseño como en música ese nivel se zarpa en onírico y relajante.

One of the more influential games of years past. It's a fun, strange little game that for it's time must've been quite the oddity to explore. For me personally, it's filled with a lot of nostalgia, despite the fact that my aimless wandering when I was younger never got me to see much of the game at all - which is why I recently decided to try and play the game proper, as I had never gotten spoiled about it's contents and wished to see if there really was more to the game than I initially believed.

And whilst I liked replaying it and puzzling together the long lost memories of when I had first played it, I really wish this game would have done more in terms of laying out actual events - to include short cutscenes, some form of interpretative dialogue or direction, and bring just a bit more cohesion to a game that is purposefully vague. 

I absolutely adore this game, but can't help but wish it had something 'more' to it.

133972751.review:
Kikiyama's classic Yume Nikki is still worth experiencing in 2023

I say experience because Yume Nikki isn't a game you play. It's a world you get lost in consumed by sounds and sights unlike anything you or me have ever seen.
In a time now where games have become more about appearing like blockbuster movies you interact with and spend most of that time watching hours of cutscenes just to nake you care, Yume Nikki does this instantly without saying a single word.

There's something extremely psychological about this game that falls into a few others that just carry this unique ambiance that will leave an impression on you much like getting a beer from your fridge. You might not want to take a sip everyday, maybe not even for weeks or months. But it will always be there when you fancy getting a light buzz.

Yume Nikki is a comfort game to some, maybe even an unsettling visual mess to others, or just boring to some. What you get out of this isn't an objective or a goal. It's about the journey and letting yourself get lost in this strange, abstract, lonesome, disconnected world that will make you feel as much as you put into it. So give it your time and your attention. It's always worth it.

133955320.review:
Yume Nikki is an interesting experience of a game with a lot of abstract imagery and odd symbolism. The game gave off an overall theme of death in my opinion with much of its visuals, interestingly choosing to do this most overtly with a sort of what I assume to be an Aztec art style in some of the more easily accessible locations. Although I believe that death and a sort of gloomy atmosphere of loneliness hangs over much of this game’s environments, I mostly felt a sense of eagerness for exploration to see what I might find next from various interactions in the unique world the game presents.

Part of my motivation for playing this somewhat niche game was having played games like Omori, Quantum Eternity, and 21 The World. The inspiration from this game I believe can be felt in all these what you might call derivative works to varying degrees. I highly recommend checking out the previously mentioned games if you haven’t already. 

While the game does have an “end goal” it is not the focus of the game, and this goal may not even be immediately apparent as you explore the diverse scenery of the dream worlds your character traverses. The only form of in progression in this game, aside from exploration, is collecting “effects” by interacting with some parts of environments. Effects are a sort of cosmetic collectable that the player can apply to themselves, however, not all these effects are purely cosmetic. Some effects grant the ability interact with some environments in a different way than having no effect equipped, two examples of effects that are not wholly cosmetic would be the stoplight and the bicycle. Using the stoplight allows the player to halt certain aspects of the environment that they are in, and the bicycle allows the player to move faster, which is quite important as some locations are rather large. In total there are 24 effects for the player to find throughout their journey. Personally, I was only able to find 20/24 effects before I had to look up a guide on how to find the rest as some of them are a little cryptic to obtain blind.

Overall, I would recommend this game as it provides an interesting experience that doesn’t require a large time investment to see something interesting or intriguing. Although the game does have an ending, I do not believe that the player should be incredibly stressed to reach this ending as much of the enjoyment for me at least came from exploring the environment. If you do have trouble collecting all effects to reach the ending, I would recommend looking up a guide to help finish off the effects collection.

133161901.review:
Yume Nikki is a lovely and atmospheric exploration game in which you have to explore various dream worlds that consist of varied themes. It's a rather simple game, but it manages to be incredibly unique and interesting nonetheless, as shown by its ability to spawn several fanmade works and be referenced through countless indie titles. 

The actual exploration of the game is generally what I would consider easy, you simply walk around and take in the atmosphere usually without fear of danger (there are very slight occasions you may need to escape an enemy). Your goal is to collect various "effects" hidden through the dream worlds, and for most of them, it is rather simple to do since finding them is the only true challenge. There are about two effects that might prove challenging to find, but all the others are mostly found in reasonable places to discover naturally. Along the way are plenty of intriguing sights to see, while some of them might be quite unsettling it all comes together to make a lovely artistic style.

As far as complaints go, my only one really revolves around the fact that your movement speed is pretty low. This can lead to the exploration aspect being a bit of a drag if you start needing to revisit locations. The game does have a counter to this, however, which is the inclusion of a Bicycle effect that doubles your speed; I would highly recommend finding this with a guide if you start to dislike the slow walking since it makes that problem null. 

Overall, Yume Nikki certainly lived up to its reputation in my eyes and made me once again find the enjoyment of exploration that games like Outer Wilds had to offer. I look forward to trying out some fanmade games of this, it's certainly a formula that works exceptionally well. 

Highly recommended.

The mystery of its game developer, Kikiyama, adds to the intriguing enigma shrouding Yume Nikki (although we now know they would order Rice Casserole with 3 Types of Cheese & Shrimp at Denny's. Thanks, Toby).

132917182.review:
Yume Nikki is... very interesting.

Its all about exploring these surreal and bizarre dream worlds with no dialogue. The dream worlds are range from charming, to creepy, to just plain weird. You also can find various effects which allow you to interact with the dream world in different ways, some are helpful, others are completely useless. Figuring out things that you can do within the dream world and experiencing all these bizarre worlds, its a very unique experience.

That being said the exploration and making "progress" can be a little dull sometimes. Searching for effects or deeper dream worlds mostly involve walking around the wrapping map for minutes finding nothing before you stumble into a tiny point of interest by pure chance. Using a guide can help, but it also spoils the experience of encountering the more unique dream worlds and scenarios first hand which is a huge part of playing Yume Nikki in the first place. Its a game that's absolutely best experienced blind, but also you really want some guidance to stop hitting dead ends.
It is free so it is that the very least worth giving it a try, but its definitely not everyone's thing. 

[strike]all in all 10/10. i love weird, creepy, cryptic s%&#.[/strike]

130238415.review:
Sometimes dreams can have a crucial meaning. The personal conflicts and emotions that we experience in our daily lives are reflected in our dreams.

Yume Nikki (which means Dream Diary) is about a girl who every time she goes to sleep has complex nightmares that haunt her and in which she must explore different locations/worlds and face her deepest fears...
To conclude, it's an indie game that doesn't expect to be understood, you may find it difficult to interpret the story or find a logic but I leave it to your imagination.

Despite being quite an old game from the 2000s, it's a gem among the classic RPG Maker horror games.
Whether you like the game or not is up to you.

129347297.review:
I don't usually go on a rant (and I never even make reviews) but this 'game' made me do this.

This is NOT a game. I still played this knowing that it was meant to be more of a thought-provoking, artistic piece but it was excruciatingly boring, unimaginative, purposeless, and infuriating. There is no point to any construct or ability in the game. You're 'meant' to just go around looking for random items that do absolutely nothing and serve little to no effect (ha ha) on anything that can be construed as progress. It might have been a little more worth playing if the music was good or if the art was anything other than blob-with-a-mouth. Yume Nikki pretends to be a game, for example you can get money which can get lives which do nothing whatsoever because you can't even die in the game since there are no enemies. There's no dialogue and all you do is walk into endless looping rooms until you find some random NPC to give you poop hair (which also does nothing but the flies were funny ig). After 5 hours of play-through I just gave up, uninstalled the game, and watched the ending which is so incredibly stupid.

The fans of this game love coming up with theories and interpretations. Good for them I guess, but I can't help thinking that they're putting meaning to something that doesn't even exist. If that's your thing then go ahead. But honestly this game is a waste of time. It may have saved some people's lives(??) but the only way it will save my life is when it's gone from my PC entirely. Thank you Yume Nikki for leaving my library to make room for other games worth my time.

128551562.review:
Before playing Yume Nikki, I already played though OMORI. That was actually the reason I found out about this game. I was reading things online about OMORI and heard it was inspired by this game. Knowing how much I enjoyed OMORI, I decided to give this game a shot.

Yume Nikki isn't like any game I've played before. It revolves around pure exploration, with nothing being told directly to you since there is no dialogue. The only time anything was explained was the tutorial, but it didn't explain all the possible actions. The gameplay consist of going to sleep to enter the dream world and picking areas to go explore. As you explore, you find effects that can alter the gameplay.  

There is a lot to explore, with some areas accessible only through events with chance, so looking things up seems necessary at times since you wouldn't know to do something a certain way. I would advise waiting until you've explored almost everything before committing to looking anything up, but that's just a recommendation. There is an ending to the game, but I also needed to look up how to do that.

Overall, I enjoyed the gameplay a lot. It was refreshing to have a game solely based off exploration, but it did lead to confusion at times. I also could feel the inspiration OMORI had while I was playing this game. The overarching concepts were the same, but the gameplay and presentation were very different. I would definitely recommend this game, but with the catch of being prepared to look things up since it's near impossible to assume a 1/64 chance for some events.

Collect all the effects and put them in the nexus. Don't use a guide, just enjoy the ride.

What I do recommend is to look online for the quadruple speed glitch, and if you're having trouble in the, red maze map, to either see how many exits there are in it and count them to make sure you've been through all of them, or to look at the red maze map online because it actually is huge. 128284820.review:
Yume Nikki is basically like taking acid but as a visual walkthrough. This game isn't about gameplay, but about an experience and adventure. I found the game super surreal and scary somehow, Yume Nikki does a perfect job at putting you uneased at all times, even though nothing really happens; the music soundtrack (which is now one of my favourites of all time) and visual really fit perfectly together with setting an atmosphere of each world and section. Going through each discovery and place was very unsettling on the undertone, but I couldn't stop playing without finding all the effects. 

I'm a sucker for music and oh boy this game really made me love it, even though it's super unnerving as you're this girl who's in my perspective is a shut-in that escapes life from dreaming. I think the dreams portray what the girl is feeling with the creepiness, with some symbolism of the end on stairs, the creepy ladies that I thought to be an abusive mother from trauma. This game says very little and put everything up to the audience's interpretation, which is amazingly genius that this very simple old game can resonate with so many people and be popular in the world of 4k graphics and triple A titles.

Overall, it's a masterpiece to me and the art and community is amazing for this niche game. Play if you like 2d Japanese edgy games.

124610591.review:
Yume Nikki is not for everyone. It is very slow and there is very little actual 'game'. The experience is almost entirely exploring open areas searching for something interesting among a sea of fantastical things which are paradoxically mundane. I actually found the experience to be similar to browsing 4chan, as it is a very meandering activity, with some unsettling or even disturbing undertones, where you genuinely have no idea what you will encounter next.

Somewhat frustratingly, it is not plausible to actually reach the credits of the game without either spending several hours meticulously combing every single area or using a guide. Luckily, there are spoiler-lite guides on the community page that can point you in the right direction while still letting you discover everything at your own pace. I tried this game in high school and found it boring, but I enjoyed it when I came back to it a few years later. To enjoy Yume Nikki, you need to be in the right mental state and not be expecting something that it isn't (ie a more traditional video game).

124352765.review:
For its day, which was the early-mid 2000s, Yume Nikki is an incredibly creative and out-there experience which you really could not find anywhere else, at least without really, really digging for it. It's extremely weird, surreal, and a lot of times just straight creepy, with strange imagery and artwork, unsettling music, and weird random events that you sometimes come across. 

To my 2022 Gamer(TM) self, I find it a decent bit boring, as a lot of the exploration, which is 99.99% of this game's "gameplay", can become very tedious and grating since your character is so slow (until you get a bike in a random area, but even then it can drag). This also is compounded by the fact that many areas are found numerous layers into one of Yume Nikki's main hub world doors, and are connected in maze-like ways that make very little sense if not none at all, which can make exploration more irritating. You find little abilities here and there which are used in certain obtuse puzzles or secrets, but that makes up a small portion of what you do in total. With this in mind, though, please understand: 

***This is not a game in the literal sense. It is more an avant-garde A/V experience, so do not play this expecting riveting gameplay, a fantastic story, or constant events/action. It is less something to play and more something to just look at or listen to. It is completely okay to want more than that, but do not be surprised if you do and when you play Yume Nikki, you get bored like I did. Do not make my mistake.***

If you want to experience weird imagery, strange music and audio, and one of the inspirations for many RPGs to come in its future, by all means, play Yume Nikki: After all, it's free. If you are looking for something along the lines of this game's (semi-distant) descendants a la Omori or Undertale, just [re]play those instead.

If you are trying to complete the game without help like I did, most of the game was writing down notes and drawing maps so that I knew where I was actually going. I spent several hours trying to find everything in a certain red labyrinth (Ill admit that most of that time was spent taking screenshots and putting them together). This could be a good or bad thing but their isn't any obvious story laid out for you. There isn't any dialog so you try to figure out what is going on by examining the environment. Artistically, this game goes above any other pixel graphic game that I have played. It plays around with perspectives and art styles to make unique and interesting environments to explore. This game can be a little scary and overwhelming at times, but I really love it! I really liked Yume Nikki. Definitely going to get further into it.

Yume Nikki is a surreal sleigh ride of a classic video game. In this game, you play as a young hikikomori girl named Madosuki. She is inside an apartment. Either choosing never to leave or because of her mental state, she falls into a deep sleep & enters the dream world. The goal of this game is to explore it, collect everything it has to offer, then to deposit everything you found into the hub by pressing 1. 
A guide of at least some sort is recommended, but only after you have completed all that you can on your own. It can take years to beat without one. I used this video because it tells you where you need to go when stuck without spoiling the ending. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VQq-JdlxsRM
I would rate this game a solid 9/10. The only thing stopping it from that 10 is that it doesn't tell you what would be essential knowledge for game completion, such as that by pressing down 1, you could cause your current effect you have equipped to do something. 
Keep in mind while playing; It is not the destination that makes the game special, it is the journey.

123614227.review:
Un juego de terror muy poco conocido pero excelente y precursor de los videojuegos de terror psicológico modernos.


Yume Nikki es un juego de terror psicológico en el que controlamos a Madotsuki y viajamos a través de sus sueños por toda clase de mundos tétricos y perturbadores.

Se trata de un juego del año 2004 hecho por RPG Maker que fue pionero del terror psicológico moderno, creando las bases y el concepto que usan hoy en día muchos juegos de este género.

Siendo un juego del 2004, sigue dando mucho miedo y eso que no tiene ni un solo screamer ni nada que te vaya a asustar de golpe porque no los necesita, pues el horrible diseño de sus niveles acompañado por su espeluznante música, hace que este juego dé más miedo que el susto más chocante que pueda dar un screamer.




El objetivo en Yume Nikki es dormir y conseguir efectos en los diferentes mundos de los sueños de Madotsuki para después dejarlos en la Sala de Puertas (también conocido como el nexo).

Y esta es toda la información que sabrás. Nunca sabrás nada más allá de estas instrucciones  iniciales del juego.

No sabrás nunca quien es la protagonista. Ni que ve en sus sueños. Si son cosas aleatorias o representaciones de algún trauma o algo con un mínimo de sentido.

Aún así, este juego tiene una wiki con todo tipo de información. Desde los NPC decorativos de cada escenario, hasta las posibles teorías que han dado los jugadores.



Por eso digo que este juego fue adelantado a su tiempo.

Antes de Limbo, Inside, Little Nightmares y todos estos juegos de terror carentes de historia o propósito, pero que dejan muchas incógnitas haciendo que la gente se interese por ellas por querer averiguar acerca de su trasfondo, investigando a los diferentes personajes, lugares y toda clase de elementos que pudieran dar lógica a un universo que no tiene sentido, Yume Nikki ya lo tenía todo!

Y es que, si bien esto lo vemos hoy como lo más normal del mundo, sobretodo en este tipo de juegos, en su momento esto fue un antes y un después en el mundo de los videojuegos.




En cuanto a la jugabilidad pues es simplemente un walking simulator donde debemos adentarnos en una barbaridad de escenarios a cada cual más terrorífico que el anterior.

Y no, no son 12 mundos en total (las 12 puertas de la Sala de puertas), sino que hay muchos más mundos ocultos donde se conectan unos con otros y algunos solo son accesibles navegando por lugares muy específicos y que son muy difíciles de encontrar, lo que los convierte en mundos profundos.

Muchos mundos, al igual que NPC entre muchos otros elementos, son solo decorativos y no hacen avanzar el progreso del juego, pero ayudan a darle más vida al extraño universo formado a través de los sueños de Madotsuki, lo que incita más a explorar todo.




Y antes de terminar con mi reseña, quiero advertir de una cosa para quien nunca haya jugado a este juego y le de curiosidad probarlo (sobretodo porque es gratis).

Mira, Yume Nikki es una arma de doble filo: la mayor virtud de este juego es, a su vez, su peor defecto:

Y esto es que el juego NUNCA te dice nada más allá de las instrucciones iniciales.


Por una parte esto es FANTÁSTICO porque le da esa aura de misterio que hace que uno piense: ¿Qué tan profundo es este juego? ¿Cuantos mundos hay? ¿Qué cosas me voy a encontrar? ¿Qué lo más horrible que voy a ver y dónde está?

Esta ignorancia de que nunca sabes por donde estas, hasta donde puedes llegar y que te vas a encontrar pues genera una inquietud que hace que la experiencia dé mucho miedo, sobretodo la primera vez que no sabes nada.

Y esto no hace que el juego sea vuelva difícil. Si te pierdes, siempre puedes pulsar la tecla 9 para que Madotsuki se despierte y empieces desde el principio sin perder progreso.



Sin embargo, esto se acaba volviendo FRUSTRANTE. 

Llega un punto en el que ya no sabes que hacer y el juego no te dice como llegar al final.

Sabes que tiene un final, que es dejando los efectos en la Sala de puertas, pero no te dice cuantos efectos hay ni como usarlos.

Y si, los efectos pueden usarse con la tecla 1 después de equiparlos desde el menú con la tecla ESC. ¿Sabes cuando te dice esto el juego? NUNCA.


Al principio es fácil conseguir efectos porque solo has de buscar el elemento diferenciador del nivel (por ejemplo, llegas a un bosque que hay muchos arboles y dibujos pero solo ves una rana; esa rana te da un efecto).

Pero luego llega un punto en el que ya no sabes que hacer y te pasas viajando todo el rato en los mismos sitios buscando efectos y sin encontrar nada, lo que se pierde la sensación de terror y se gana la sensación de perder el tiempo.

El juego no da NI UNA SOLA PISTA y ni siquiera te dice cuantos efectos debes conseguir ni que hacer después para ver el final.
Spoiler: [spoiler]Son 24 efectos, sin contar las instrucciones. Cuando los dejas todos en la Sala de Puertas debes despertar con la tecla 9 y salir al balcón[/spoiler]


Como os digo, esto es una arma de doble filo porque por una parte se consigue una mejor sensación de terror al principio, pero luego se pierde y empiezas a pensar que estás perdiendo el tiempo.

Solución: Mirar la wiki del juego y usarla como guía para poder acabarlo.














En resumen:

Un juego de terror psicológico muy bueno que sigue dando miedo en 2022 y lo seguirá dando hasta el fin de los tiempos.

Yume Nikki es un juego muy recomendado para quien le guste este género.
Lo que yo recomiendo es jugar con las luces apagadas, con los auriculares puestos y con el móvil en silencio para tener la máxima inmersión posible.

Solo cuando ya no sepas que hacer y empieces a dar vueltas por los mundos recorriendo los mismos lugares buscando los últimos efectos que no encuentras, es cuando recomiendo que mires la wiki porque seguir buscando es una pérdida de tiempo. Hay tantos secretos y tan bien escondidos, que serán casi imposibles de encontrar sin una guía.

Sea como sea, disfruta de uno de los mejores juegos de terror jamás hechos. No lo subestimes por su impopularidad o sus sencillos gráficos de 32 bits.


Gracias por su lectura.

123567742.review:
I played this years ago when it was a shareware videogame without a steam release. It's unchanged as far as I can tell from the original game. It works OK on newer PCs but due to the engine there are some compatibility problems with certain graphics cards. I believe the vignette effect can be quite slow depending on the hardware you're using.

The game itself is a long, winding exploration of the dreams of the main character, Madotsuki. The main loop consists of sleeping in your bed and, once asleep, leaving your apartment to explore the depths of your subconscious. The goal, if there is any, is to collect all of the "effects" in the game and view the ending. While there are a couple effects that have gameplay consequences (mainly the bike, which makes you go faster, and the knife, which allows you to kill NPCs in your dreams), the vast majority of effects are purely cosmetic. There are also many randomly triggered events and sights to see, ranging from beautiful to ugly, and from serene to terrifying. It's a game which is primarily based on exploration, seeing novel sights, and getting further into your dreams than you did the night before.

I will say, however, that this game does not respect your time at all. If you don't know where to go, it can take forever to get your first effects. Without the bike, the game can feel like quite a slog. Some events trigger only very rarely and basically require you to repeatedly try to trigger them if you really want to see them for yourself. I recommend playing this game without a guide for the first few hours if you want the authentic, lost experience. But only a true masochist would play this to the end without significant help from the wiki.

121902998.review:
I know its a free game but there's just too much aimless walking around and wandering even if I use the bicycle. For a game that's so popular, it's very hollow and boring. For my taste. I ran out of patience and watched a walkthrough to get the ending. No spoilers but I realized later that this game isn't just some game that you play through. I found out that there's so much lore and weird events that go on in this universe that I wanted to know more. I went on to the fan base to get an explanation, but that wasn't enough, so I read the shitty manga. Still confused. Played the "sequel" on my Switch. I didn't play it on steam so I'll breifly talk about it here. 

Dream Diarry solidified a lot of info from the first game while also building on top of it. It was able to recreate the nostalgic universe in 3d and didn't copy the original gameplay. I thought it was a better way to visualize the universe of Yume Nikki but the sequel would probably feel empty without playing Yume Nikki first. 

In the end I say go for the whole experience. (It will break you) Get the bicycle first and use the speed glitch to be fast. That will make the experience much denser and better.

121899742.review:
In the subreddit, a user asked once which place brought the most emotions. There were lots of different answers, with personal meanings, people resonating with this or that and remembering different details. It was like sharing memories of a similar yet different journey. I think this is what defines Yume Nikki.
This "game", if we can call it a game, feels like walking in the soul of a person. So human, so abstract, so true, so harsh, so sweet, at the same time. Everyone has their attention caught in particular by something different. Everyone experiences in different ways the sceneries and events.
It is not for everyone, and I'm sure a certain portion of people might find it incredibly boring, and that's ok too. 

I think is just a game made with love.

PS: A practical advice I give you, although it's cute, the walking sound may annoy you after a while playing since you constantly hear it. There's a simple guide how to remove it if you search in the guides section, which is just removing a file in a folder ;)

Now I understand that Yume Nikki is the progenitor of RPGMaker horror games, and is nearly two decades old now. I can see why it would've got so much attention when it came out. 119859567.review:
I can see why this game has a huge cult following-even to this day in 2022! However, I do also understand where some people would have criticisms in terms of lack of direction for the game's narrative (or lack thereof one).
I personally get overwhelmed when a game does not give me an objective in order to accomplish it to the fullest potential, so when a game like this just tells me to collect effects in order to get more of an experience playing the game-without much of direction to get some of those effects-this game can be a bit overwhelming. I wanted to really explore this like the game encourages me to, but when I can't interact with the larger majority of my surroundings, it becomes very taxing to explore with very little to no reward. So in order to keep myself sane, I had to lookup walkthroughs in order to get the majority of the things done here.
Despite these criticisms-I do feel like this game is worth playing. Knowing that this game inspired many other games later down the road, I do see where a lot of people get the appeal of playing as a young girl wandering around in her dreams. There are some genuinely interesting, creepy, and unsettling imagery throughout, and with the help of walkthroughs, I was able to see and experience some things that I feel like games nowadays sort of overuse and oversaturate their content with. And I also feel like this is a game that can be worth playing for in terms of not completing the story all the way through to the ending. The ending... I'll say it was very sudden for what you would expect in terms of playing a game like this. But that doesn't stop you from going back into a save and exploring more with the effects you now possess. You're able to get into areas you couldn't before, as well as have particular events occur in the game that you may have not seen in your first time exploring certain areas and worlds.
I recommend having an open mind for a game like this. Don't expect much of a story to this because that may disappoint a many of people who think stories are what make all games great. This game definitely explores a way to play without any expectation of a plot aside of a handful of indications of who they character you're playing as. Madotsuki is a girl who is homebound and escapes her reality to have a better life in her dreams. This ambiguity of the character makes you wonder of how a young child has these sorts of dreams with creepy places, strange monsters and other odd aspects occur for her in her mind. Why would the "ending" of the game occur for someone like her? Ultimately, it doesn't really matter about the past or potential future for this character. The purpose of the game is to do things presently and experience things as openly as possible.
Overall, very interesting game worth playing at least once. :)

This isn't my kind of game. So why am I recommending it?

[Minor Spoilers to Start of the Game]

This game will be EXTREMELY confusing to people who just see it in the store or who have heard of it before and decide to get it, which was what happened for me. Within 10-20 minutes, you will get "stuck", or at least what most would consider "stuck". You're going to get lost once you've explored for a bit, which is why I was forced to google thinking I was doing something was wrong.
In reality, this isn't an ordinary game, it's extremely original, and more of a surreal experience than a game. It's like a piece of abstract art that you're able to explore. I've heard that there is an ending, but I have no idea how to get to it whatsoever. This game seems really cool, but I'm more personally into games that are at least a bit more adventurous than this one, so I couldn't finish it.

I truly recommend this game, because it seems like a game you'd either not care about at all, or love deeply and be super immersed. I wish I liked this game because it seems very interesting, but I couldn't beat it. Still, you should definitely play it to see if you'll like it, it's free!

118553444.review:
[h1]This Game Has Been Praised On The Altar But It Can't Bring The Slightest Joy[/h1]

In 2018, a game called "Dream Diary" quietly appeared on the STEAM platform, and in the form of a free gift, all players were welcomed with open arms.  This game, classified as an independent game, is not well-known in the circle of ordinary gamers, but it is a rough and eye-catching rough stone in the field of fan games. ​​

 The 0.00 version was launched in 2004, and then to the 0.10 final version in 2007, the "Dream Diary" developed on the basis of "RPG Maker 2003", all the art and music materials are independently handled by the author.  In the production cycle of more than three years, this work and its author appeared and disappeared silently, which gave a surprise to the fan game circle of the year, and left countless mysteries.  This diary, which records twelve dreams, is like reading comprehension without the correct answer, allowing players to freely imagine.  To this day, fans have left more than four thousand "Very Positive" comments for the STEAM version of "Dream Diary", but this "praise" have nothing to do with "fun". Not only is it not fun, it will make people feel depressed, bored, depressed, and even have an uncomfortable reaction in severe cases.  It is precisely because of this that the crown of "Dream Diary" only shines brightly in the field of small fan games.

 The player enters "Dream Diary", and the movable space is only one bedroom and one terrace.  A picture tube TV with an old game console, a desk with a diary, a bookshelf, a single bed, this is all about the world of waking up.  In the room lived a girl with double ponytails and drowsy eyes all the time. The girl never spoke and had nothing to do except play game consoles and swivel chairs in the room.  There is a door on the upper left of the room, and no one knows what is on the other side of the door.  When the player investigates the door, the girl will only shake her head and refuse, not knowing whether she can't go out or doesn't want to go out.  So bored, the girl had no choice but to sleep with her head down.  Entering the dream, the girl actually stood on the terrace outside the house.  The sky turned dark, and an uncomfortable BGM sounded.  Back in the house, the game console was gone.  Investigated the door again, and actually opened it in a dream.  After opening the door in the dream, the player finally entered the game world of "Dream Diary".

 Doors, slightly spiritually polluted paintings.  More than a dozen doors with different shapes look at different dream worlds.  Each world is almost completely different, and ordinary natural scenery is not uncommon, but many worlds can make players spontaneously fall into unpleasant emotions.  The art style of individual levels is influenced by the Paracas civilization, with bright but extreme color matching, strangely shaped model units, and disturbing background music that has no melody at all, polluting it almost all the time.  player's heart.

 Even in levels that don't look so bad, there's still no gameplay to speak of.  "Dream Diary" has no teaching or guidance, and there is no text in the entire game.  The player entered dozens of huge dream realms out of thin air, scurrying around like a brainless fly.  The infinite loop map, the props that can only be found by continuous trial and error, finally found the NPC, and it was only found.

 Fans of the game began to question, "Dream Diary" is not like a normal person can do it.  Its visual and auditory double pollution is so serious that it can make some players feel physically uncomfortable, so that it is labeled as "spiritual curiosity".  People began to suspect that the low-key and introverted author, ききやま, who developed the game independently, may suffer from some mental illness.  He may be like a girl, staying behind closed doors, suffering from autism, depression and other diseases, and "Dream Diary" is a world that concretizes the dreams in the patient's brain.

Those players who stayed in the world of "Dream Diary" gradually found the game's strategy.  Each world has hidden props, and the purpose of the game is to collect props with various prerequisites and put them at the entrance of the dream.  Interestingly, whenever a girl uses a prop, there will be some corresponding changes, such as changing her appearance, stepping on a bicycle, taking a kitchen knife, etc.  The corresponding changes of these props can also trigger the interaction of the few NPCs in the game.

 Of course, all these conjectures about "Dream Diary" have not been answered by the author ききやま.  The divergent space of "Dream Diary" has become larger and larger, allowing more and more foreign players to come into contact with this magical and strange fan game.  "Dream Diary" does not require any translation except the game menu, which is why players around the world feel the game world of ききやま without any difference.  The brain hole creation boom triggered in Japan has also continued to be staged overseas, and the process has intensified. For a time, "a fan game developed based on the fan game "Dream Diary" appeared.

 "Dream Diary" has not been a big hit, but it has become a wonderful personal show for players.  We don't know what happened and what happened to the girls in "Dream Diary", but everyone has their own opinions and ideas about the game.  "Dream Diary" prompts players to constantly explore this unfriendly world, but also makes people think deeply about the spiritual world of individual groups.  After "Dream Diary", its shadow can occasionally be seen in fan games, and the well-respected "Under the Legend" seems to be influenced by it, and some easter eggs that look like it are arranged, which triggers players' secondary creation.  .  However, no one has been able to make a work as terminally ill as "Dream Diary".

 At the end of the story, the girl met all the friends in the dream world and collected all the props.  However, dreams are dreams after all, pinching his cheeks to wake up, even if they left them in the diary, the bedroom door still could not be opened.  Only the stairs to the sky on the terrace are waiting for you and her.

118378117.review:
Yume Nikki is an old, vintage indie game from the early 2000s which, aside from a couple of moments here and there, has very much stood the test of time overall. 

It has countless different areas which you can explore in search of the many effects and hidden events and effectively makes exploration fun and addicting. Despite there being secrets which I wouldn't have known about without the wiki and despite often using maps found online, I feel like that only adds to the experience, as it's the equivalent of receiving directions for hidden treasure. The visuals and the sound design are simplistic, but very effective and serve their purpose of creating a, sometimes creepy and sometimes more mellow, atmosphere. 

Overall, I think the game isn't for everyone, as it's largely nonlinear and confusing, but to those who love early 2000s charm, Japanese video game culture, exploration games or (minor Omori spoilers)[spoiler]Omori's blackspace sections[/spoiler], this is right up your alley and I strongly recommend it!

118299132.review:
A classic and simple exploration game that's inspired countless psychological and walking-sim games in the couple decades since its original release. Shows its age and humble RPG maker origins in plenty of ways (and many of the elements in it have long since become cliché), but still conveys a uniquely disturbing and vibrant atmosphere that definitely holds up.

Being laboriously slow and barebones in presentation, it's definitely not a game for everyone, and you certainly won't find any modern polish or consistency here. There's even some [spoiler]straight jumpscares[/spoiler] and other questionable inclusions, so the game is far from some purely atmospheric, distilled art piece. The emphasis is more on variety and experimentation than the individual quality of each component, after all. If you can handle all that, though, the game offers a unique, surreal experience for you to discover at your own pace, that sticks in your mind for a long, long time.

I know other folks find this game to be one of the best games out there, but for me it wasnt. 

I understand the point of the game is the exploration and the themes and ambiance, (which is pretty solid!) That the point of the game is the wandering and the mindless confusion of a dream. For me, it really wasnt filling anything. 

To the games credit, it has wonderful tone and depth. But the game sometimes comes off as full of itself, but lacking any meaning or real point of the story. 

If you enjoy playing a game without a guide, this game is certainly not for you. a Guide is absolutely NECESSARY to get through the game. 

One point i will give the game is its random events which are varied and fun, however they are not consistent, and sometimes require you to trek back to that location to experience the full game, which for some events can take a VERY long and tedious task to get through to experience. This game is NOT for completionists in my opinion.

If you are someone who loves atmosphere, great score, and a truly open world, this game is for you.

But for me, While the ending was a bit jarring and does answer some questions found in the game, I cannot say i will be going through the process of finding all this game has to offer.

116990251.review:
Yume Nikki: A once in a lifetime experience

I just beat this game a few days ago. After reading a bunch of fan theory's and video's trying their best to explain the oddities of this game, I think I am ready to post my review of this game. I just want to say this, I have no nostalgia or knowledge of Yumi Nikki prior to this point. I lived under a rock and never played this game and while I knew what it was about, I had no knowledge of the games contents. That being said, this game is a god damn masterpiece and it deserves all of the hype and praise it receives. 

I went into this with high expectations and it somehow met them. I understand that many players find this game incredibly boring, and while I disagree I do see their point. I personally see this game as more of an experience, not really a game. It is mostly about exploring the world of Madotsuki's dreams; Madotsuki being a hikkiomori who escapes her small room through her dreams using the Nexus. The Nexus is the games hub, a large room filled with 12 different doors. Each door takes Madotsuki to a different dream world. Exploring these dream worlds take you to smaller dream worlds which can connect you to the other bigger dream worlds. The goal of the game is to collect all 24 'effects'. Each effect changes Madotsuki's appearance and gives her a small thing she can do. You can find them in the dream worlds scattered around, either by interacting with NPC's or certain elements of the level. Beating the game requires you to drop all 24 effects into the Nexus, therefore completing the dream diary. However, the main appeal of the game is not the effects in my opinion. The reason I love this game is because it can tell you an intresting yet sad story with no dialogue and only through visuals, the ending and the contents of Madotsuki's dreams. Many of the seemingly random aspects of the game have a hidden meaning, and since the creator has kept their mouth shut on any fan theory's surrounding the game everything about it is truly left up to your own interpretation. This is easily the best part of Yumi Nikki, piecing together your own story based on the most random and horrific visuals Madotsuki's dreams have to offer. And believe me, many of the popular fan theory's surrounding this game are incredibly dark and may be uncomfortable for some people. Some conclusions you can come to may be standard struggles or insecurities many people have to deal with, or extremely taboo and sensitive topics. I cannot mention the most popular theory about this game for obvious reasons and although it has a lot of merit to it, I  personally do not think it is the sole reason Madotsuki is like this. I believe that it isn't the main reason, but rather a major component to how she ended up this way.

Overall I think this game is spectacular and I honestly am kind of mad at myself for not playing it a lot sooner. There is literally no reason to not try this game out, it is free afterall. This game is a work of art in my eyes and everyone should play though it at least once in their life. That is all, give Yumi Nikki a chance and I guarantee you will fall in love.

116709562.review:
Back in the days of the Great Recession, there were many adults and children alike who simply did not have the funds to buy all of the games that they wanted. I was introduced to the internet at a very young age, computers always fascinated me, and although I had an xbox, I seeked to do whatever I wished on the computer specifically. 

I remember back when I was an older child, I wanted to play games, but my dilemma is that the only money my parents were willing to spend on the computer any further was the DSL internet (those were the days...), sometimes I would be lucky and get a AAA game every few months or so, and I'd play these games over and over and over again. 

But alas, you can only play your favorite games so many times, if you play them too much, they will eventually no longer be your favorite, and I needed some new material, I got into freeware and indie games for a large portion of my childhood, and early on I was lucky enough to be graced with Yume Nikki.

Simply put, I am a Yume Nikki veteran, I remember playing Yume Nikki before there were English patches, being totally entranced by this game. It's a simple RPG maker game, but this game did something different. Yume Nikki wasn't an RPG, it had no RPG elements, it didn't even have dialogue, it told its story through its imagery, leaving the details up to the viewers interpretation. It's legacy is seen even to this day, hanging up in the ranks with games like Corpse Party, a LEGENDARY horror franchise.

I recommend that you take the time to experience a little bit of RPG Maker history, and see why this game is a cult classic after all of these years!

114698441.review:
RPG Maker strikes again! 

Yume Nikki is one of hundreds of low effort retro-pixel JRPG ripoffs spamming the Steam catalog, made with the RPG Maker video game construction kit... in their own words, "Our easy to use tools are simple enough for a child."  Like all RPG Maker "games", this is essentially a bunch of low quality/canned assets from RPG Maker coupled with a cringeworthy high school anime club weeaboo fan fiction. Basically, these guys didn't make a game, they filled out a couple of templates in a construction kit.

This isn't even a proper game, it's an advertisement intended to draw attention to the publishers full game, Yume Nikki Dream Diary (which isn't even an RPG Maker game!).  They're charging $20 USD for that trash.  Ouch.  This advertisement is a short, basic story driven "walking sim" that outlines the themes for Yume Nikki Dream Diary in an attempt to encourage people to go buy it.  Ugh.  There's no meaningful interaction in this advertisement.

Like all RPG Maker games, the poor quality engine displays badly in fullscreen and doesn't have full HD support or any graphics tweaking options.  Resolution is locked and the game features 2D retro pixel art asset flips.  All of this makes this unacceptable for any dedicated modern PC gamer. 

Gamers who want a good retro JRPG experience would be better off playing the originals, like Final Fantasy, Star Ocean or Chrono Trigger.  Leave this terrible fan fiction in the shovelware bundles where it belongs.

While this looks to be free, it's free because it's an advertisement as the developer seeks to bypass paying Valve for store front space by instead paying $100 USD and listing an advert as a full game, to mislead gamers.

112879312.review:
Yume Nikki is a surreal and bizarre experience shrouded in mystery and symbolism with little to no story for added spectacle, the rich atmosphere accompanied by the gentle and sometimes unnerving soundtrack makes for a quality game that feels as real as any dream. You play as a female character named Madotsuki, who lives alone in her apartment complex with the only view to the outside being the balcony. She is doesn't seem to want to go outside and the only source of entertainment is a made-up NES/Famicom game called NASU, it's barely worth the mention and doesn't affect the game at all. The only real way to make progress is to go to bed and sleep, once you've fallen asleep you're in the dream world, leaving Madotsuki's room will take you to a realm called the "Nexus" with several doors leading to different dream worlds. 

So you may be asking, what is the goal of Yume Nikki? The objective of the game is to traverse dream worlds locked behind different doors and collect abilities called "effects", along the way you will encounter strange imagery and odd residents of the dream world who just seem to go about their business and pay no sight of mind to you as you continue your journey to seek and collect different effects. The worlds you will encounter will range from an innocent world full of snow to a world filled with grotesque body horror full of arms and eyes, the game may not be what it seems as it will surprise you with it's imaginative and chilling images. In between the worlds there are events that can view, some can only appear under a 1/6 or 1/4 of a chance and may happen at random so be on the lookout for anything different or try searching for them. 

Despite the game being 18 years old the visuals and game-play still holds up well today. Everything about the game breathes charm and curiosity along with an added sprinkle of mystery and unease, it should go without saying that everyone should at least play this game once their life. Even for those who may not have given much thought I'd urge them to give it a chance. It may not be for everyone regardless of play style, but you'll find something to appreciate in this special game that has even inspired and influenced the creator of OMORI and LISA.

The game isn't without imperfections however as there are a few things in the game which should be mentioned. The game is non-linear but rather open world and free to explore with several areas having a pathway the leads deeper into another part of the dream world. This may sound fine, but the way game wants you progress is too expansive and confusing. Let's imagine a hypothetical scenario where there's an effect/event somewhere around the map, to find it you may have to search in every direction until you find as it could be a specific spot. So you waste time looking up, down, left, right, northwest, southwest, northeast, and southeast until you finally find it. What I just summarized is what you'll be doing 90% of the game and it can get pretty old real quick. The game-play structure of Yume Nikki isn't flawed but it is far from peak game design, mostly tedious and boring. It's not a deal breaker but you will notice it when adrenaline of trying to find a new effect or event comes into play. 

Another problem with the game is travelling, let's say you found a specific dream world within one of the many dream worlds and want to visit it again. Sorry to say, but You are out of luck. The game has a few connections to certain parts of the dream worlds like the [spoiler]elevator in graffiti world that takes you to the mall/subway area[/spoiler], but not all of them are connected like a big maze, so most of the time you'll just have to re-count your steps and hope you find it again. This is very annoying but not a deal breaker, just an inconvenience. I want to talk about the effects real quick and talk about how they're kind of underutilized. I already mentioned how in the game you have to collect several effects to beat the game, what I didn't mention is 1/4 of them are useful and the rest are useless. Most of the other effects don't really affect the game and are purely cosmetic, personally I thought it was a wasted opportunity to not utilize them in certain areas to progress and receive new effects or progress deeper into the game's worlds. In the end, they only exist to progress the game physically, not narratively.

Although these issues can be seen as minor, they can be a little grating. Not enough to ruin the game, but it can make a slow slog-fest even more tedious than it need to be. Overall, I still stand by my opinion that this game is worthy of attention and praise. Whether you understand the game or not, there is no denying Yume Nikki's influence seen through other noteworthy games. The ending alone will leave you speechless and have you make connections through all the metaphorical imagery you seen up until this point and have you ask questions by the end. This game may not be a masterpiece, but it sure as hell is one the most important magnum opus to come from RPG Maker, you won't be disappointed.
