112567541.review:
It's been said many times before, and it's worth reiterating again: Yume Nikki isn't a video game, it's an experience, and one that everyone should try regardless of their affinity for games.

There are no real objectives in Yume Nikki. Despite being made in RPG Maker, the game is entirely devoid of RPG elements, and the focus is instead on freedom of exploration around various dream environments. There are several different equippable 'effects' you can find by interacting with various objects and NPCs. Some of these are useful, some of them are purely cosmetic. Finding all of the effects provides the closest thing to an objective to be found in the game, but is entirely optional, and one can find all of the effects while still missing out on a majority of the game.

The mysterious and elusive creator behind this game used RPG Maker not to make an RPG, but rather as a canvas for an unusual and abstract piece of art. Playing Yume Nikki feels like getting caught in a trance; the bizarre and striking visuals coupled with the dreamy atmosphere and ethereal music make for an absorbing experience. It's easy to become lost for long periods of time, exploring as much as you can, taking in the scenery and strange scenes that unfold in front of you. I'd say that above all else, Yume Nikki is equivalent to a digital art gallery.

The tension and horror aspects can't be understated, either. Despite its outdated and pixelated visuals, the game's ethereal and gripping atmosphere can lead to feelings of dread and even paranoia as one delves into the darker corners of the dream world, feeling utterly alone amidst empty planes of otherworldly scenery, occasionally littered with abstract beings incapable of human speech. Yume Nikki is infamous for its influence on indie games and the horror genre as a whole, and even an hour or two of playing should tell you why.

Coming back to this game on steam many years later, its effect hasn't worn with time and is still just as evocative and absorbing as it was the first time I played all those years ago. I highly recommend this game to anyone who has yet to experience it for themselves.

Alright, after a long time, I'm here to rewrite my old review of this game. I rated it positive before, but now I wish I could rate it even better. I've revisited this game for the greater half of a decade by now, and somehow the game keeps luring me back. Now, this would make sense if it were a game that got frequent updates, story, or even basic dialogue. But that's what makes this all the more puzzling. Yume Nikki does not have **one** bit of dialogue, or **anyone** speaking for that matter. It's just a walking simulator, but it's far more entrancing than any other game I've played.
Though, this is due to the way it tells its story: setting. Words would only do harm to this masterpiece. In fact, I feel the more words I use to describe it would just be doing it more of an injustice each time. It's a once in a lifetime experience, over and over again. It's a mirror maze, with every turn another memory. It's a masterpiece, and my #1 pick for my favorite game of all time.

110367991.review:
Es definitivamente uno de los mejores juegos indie que existen, en su clase, obviamente.
La cuestión es que no es para todos, el juego es una mezcla de puzzles, un terror psicológico raro y por sobretodo, un mundo completamente surrealista, además, si no te gustan los juegos donde no hay un fin, es decir, no tienes un objetivo en claro, no lo recomiendo para nada.

Este juego es de ''mundo abierto'', por decirlo de alguna forma.
Tiene una gran infinidad de mapas, unos más raros que otros, y algunos juegan contigo, como el laberinto o el desierto, ya que todo parece igual, cuando en realidad no lo es.

Una recomendación para los nuevos jugadores:
- La cantidad de efectos, que se podría decir son el ''objetivo'' del juego, son 24, pero una vez que comenzamos tenemos ya un efecto agregado que es el tutorial, por ende pueden parar en cuanto tengan 25 efectos, pero siempre hay algo que no hemos visto, así que recomiendo seguir investigando, estoy segura de que encontrarán otra cosa.
- Recomiendo sacar los efectos principales de cada puerta primero, que son 12, y luego irse a los diferentes mapas por los que pueden acceder en ellos. Estos pueden ser portales, alcantarillas, ascensores, puertas, etc, deben buscar bien.
- Si quieren sacar el final deben dejar en el suelo todos los efectos en el mundo del sueño principal, que es donde están las 12 puertas. una vez que dejan los 24 efectos, que se convierten en huevos, hagan que Madotsuki se despierte y vayan al balcón, eso es todo.
- Yo estuve aproximadamente 6 horas jugando, pero en realidad tomas mucho más si eres nuevo, esto porque es difícil acceder a todos los mapas y saber donde encontrar cada efecto.

Certified hood classic, one of my favorite games of all time.

In Yume Nikki you play as a young girl who refuses to leave her appartment. Stricken with sudden onset boredom, you are tasked with exploring her dreams. In these dreams, your goal is to obtain the 24 different effects, and find the final escape. 

Filled with symbolism and ominous music, this game will leave you questioning everything you see.

Infamously, the game has many creepy and unnerving areas, such as the infamous white faced monster, Uboa, the strange jelly blob, Kyuu Kyuu Kun, the oddly adorable girl, Monoko, and the strange, lanky looking creature, Masada. 

This game got me somewhat famous, too. So, there is that.

109851011.review:
You are a girl: a girl who has lived but doesn't, whose existence is entirely defined by which direction she rolls in a dizzying cycle of waking and sleeping. Your life was once defined by the time between that you were awake, but lately it feels as though your dreams are the only place where you're really you. In dreams, waking life is abstracted, perverted to reflect the deep unease it all gives you, the overwhelming city buzz, the rush of connection, the excruciating isolation, all given legs, given arms, given faces. It's terrifying but it's honest. There's nothing to do in dreams, nothing to change. You only have to walk through them. Walk, walk, walk till you understand. Walk, walk, walk till it all washes over you. Walk, walk, walk till you've found yourself -- the big, the small, the recognised and the insignificant, held in your hands, corporeal -- then Google like the last three item locations because you've probably walked enough IMO.

Beautiful game! Very spooky! Draws a lot of subconscious emotion from you so it all feels very personal and intimate! The walking thing wasn't a metaphor, though, I think they call this type of game 'strand-type' now.

109677335.review: I know that many people wrote reviews like this so mine isn't special, but I decided to talk about my opinion of it regardless. I think the best way to summarise this game is: you can beat it in about forty minutes, and have one type of perception of the game, or you can play it by yourself- without guides to get each effect , and find every artifact yourself, and just explore the worlds themselves, and it is certainly worth doing. The game is incredibly large and vast, and it's honestly very delicately connected to one place and another, and it certainly works. Some things (at least for me) were "unsettling" (probably due to the music), and the game creates this simplistic yet wonderful extraction of your emotions that works. The black backdrop in most of the world creates this feeling of void and emptiness, and the looping makes it never ending. There are so many small things in this game- characters, details, worlds, that you might not notice if you don't explore far enough, and it's honestly amazing since these things don't matter to the plot but do create a much more strengthened perception of Madotsuki's dream world. The game is, surprising and unexpected. If you play it this way without knowing what comes next then you will be surprised, as the worlds are quite random (as in you could go into a world with no correlation to the former one, not that the worlds rotate), and it honestly wants you to explore because you could be sent from some disturbing place into a spaceship, or from a train onto an island, and so forth. It definitely captures how dreams are and how one can transfer from a peaceful dream that is nice to a living hell. I don't really know why but, upon playing this game (and when you get progress), the controls which are only 8 keys, do not take away from the game. It's very simple and, somehow enjoyable, probably due to just how bizarre and unique this game is still to this day in regard to how it works, and the "plot". I can't really say I love the game for characters, there isn't much attachment I gained to Madotsuki or the NPC's throughout, but it is enjoyable just because of how interesting the game is, how interesting and bizarre each environment is and just the effort that was placed into each one. I remember sometimes I accidentally did something and I got transferred into another world that I didn't even know existed in the game. It's just an experience that you should go through- maybe sit down, get something nice to drink or eat, and play for an hour or two, just exploring the worlds and finding your way (with the fandom guide maybe if you get stuck or lost), and this game will not fail to subvert your expectations. At least, that is how I felt when I played the game, as I most definitely enjoyed my experience with it, or at the least, I was kept entertained.

This game is one of those games where you ask yourself: “Where exactly am I? What am I getting myself into?” then upon these questions, you’re beginning to seek why you’re here. 

The key to be able to enjoy this game is patience, I understand why people find it boring, even I did at first, but it will become more fun if you just keep [b]exploring[/b]! Yume Nikki involves a surreal atmosphere, with lots of exploration, lots of ambient music, lots of interactive elements and NPCs. But there is exactly no storytelling nor dialogue in this game, it is open to interpret what the dreams represent. These are what exactly defines a dream, it’s all weird, yet you might forget it afterwards. 

I have enjoyed playing this game. I wish to play more games like this, where you experience being lost and trying to find your way out of this confusion. What a surreal yet calming experience!

106417249.review:
yume nikki is my favourite game. ever.

while there has been franchises and games i have found just sorta come and go, ever since i played it first i have never loved a game more. yume nikki is truly special. its deep, mysterious and atmospheric and grants an experience that no other game will ever be able to replicate. it conveys the emotions of madotsuki in a way that the player can feel the same, which no other game can do simply because of how perfect madotsuki is as a character.

madotsuki is a perfect protagonist for a game like yume nikki because she is only really an avatar. she does not speak, respond in special ways or do things against the players control. she will go wherever you take her and do whatever you make her do, there are no restrictions. yume nikki is a game about unlimited exploration and infinite discovery - there's still probably secrets the community are yet to find out to this day (the time it took to discover the river creature and the FACE event is probably enough proof to say that there's still a lot left untouched) and makes every discovery feel fresh, new and surprising. 



the following part of the review will contain mentions of topics such as suicide, depression and sexual assault. please do not read any further if that makes you uncomfortable.




playing through the game after the ending and seeing madotsuki take her own life, and knowing of the terrifying theories about rape, abuse and depression makes the game feel so, so different to play. you notice the symbolism, how the monsters and terrifying faces all seem to mean something now - madotsukis dreams portray a fear of pregnancy and genitals, her feelings of helplessness and weakness and her overbearing fear which is all shown purely through crpytic monsters and imagery. nothing feels strange and whimsical anymore, it seems dark, depressing and frightening. things like o-man's flute, poniko's daytime room and other things that once seemed happy now feel like a break from the horrors the game offers.

on the topic of o-man, my lord, o-man's encounter is probably my favourite part of the entire game. it's one of the only parts of the game that doesn't feel lonely, isolated and unnerving. it's calming and comforting, and after beating the game and learning of madotsuki's tragedy, it feels bittersweet and emotional. 

i adore everything yume nikki has to offer and it has and always will be my #1 game ever to be released.

this game is a masterclass in atmosphere and visual storytelling.

The good:
+ Very surreal [strike] world building[/strike] dream
+ Creepy atmosphere
+ Fine SFX
+ Fun exploration (only when you explore aimlessly, not looking for "Effects")

The bad:
- Unclear direction
- Some "Effects" is very difficult to be found, either due to large area, vague area design, require you to visit multiple areas in sequence or ALL of them

The ugly:
* Pure "Show, don't tell"

102432538.review:
It's hard to even really know where to begin with a game like Yume Nikki. Not only is it as remarkably influential to a particular aesthetic that you can find many indie games taking inspiration from, but the game itself is not only beloved, but also quite unusual and unique. My biggest takeaway with this is that it's yet another game in an ever-increasing list that I've played that represent why it's pointless and reductive to attempt to boil games down to things that are "objectively good" in one way or another, because if this approach was taken, then there's no doubt that this game would just be swept under the rug. After all, when taking a broad look at this, it's really little more than aimless exploration where you just walk around until you hit a dead end or find fun collectible effects, many of which do completely nothing, and yet, this is still a truly incredible experience for so many reasons an a deserved cult classic.

I feel like the biggest way in which Yume Nikki accomplishes to much is thanks to its constant vagueness. Everything about this feels obscured, disconnected, and seemingly meaningless on the surface, many areas are just large, empty spaces, sparsely populated with an object of some sort and maybe a door or two to another large, empty spaces, interactions with the various entities often result in a mere sound effect or maybe a charming little animation, and there's not even any semblance of active threat for the vast majority of the playthrough. I feel like this vagueness really contributes to the game's atmosphere and can quite easily put the player through a variety of emotions while playing, which ties nicely into the surreal nature of dreams, where scattershot events often feel loosely tied together if even that. This total emptiness combined with the short, looping music and the way you've got things like these giant, barely comprehensible beings floating in the background, or random beasts that serve no purpose end up providing the player with this profound sense of paranoia for quite a while, nothing feeling quite right and the constant barrage of this atmosphere ends up piling upon itself and resulting in one of the freakiest experiences I've had in a game.

What I truly feel makes the atmosphere of this game special however, is the way that in time, it becomes exceedingly apparent that the fear and anxiety that the player feels is less due to any imminent threat, and more to the whole idea of the fear of the unknown. Everything about the world constructed in this game feels so alien at first, doors leading to unrelated places, endlessly branching paths, constant music changes or areas dedicated to barebones, abstract imagery, and yet, this doesn't always stay quite so disconcerting. After giving the game a couple of hours, you really start to feel like you've gained some understanding of your surroundings, and those moments of finding something new, or even retreading familiar ground, end up feeling really comfy as you explore this endlessly charming, strange dream, with the seemingly endless possibilities gaining a certain sense of intrigue and excitement as opposed to just feeling daunting. I could definitely see this mostly becoming a comfort game of sorts to me, being able to once again jump in a world that's so devoid of any qualities of reality and getting immersed in the incredibly dense atmosphere all over again, with the sprawling nature of it undoubtedly revealing some new stuff that I never have seen before.

The effect system is pretty cool in the way it directly contributes to this gameplay loop, with very few of the powers actually having much of a tangible use beyond some neat events that give the game some more detail than it could first seem, but also just being able to provide a bit of a fun visual change in a way that ends up making you connect a bit more with Modotsuki. With all this said, for as much as this game might be amazing, it is definitely not without its flaws either. While the exploration is largely truly fascinating and gives some of the strongest vibes in gaming, I feel like at times it becomes more of a massive, cumbersome pain instead. I feel like there are probably a few too many areas that are almost exclusively giant, empty spaces with a couple of things sparingly spread around to the point where some of the interest in exploration gets completely lost because you're just walking across a big, scrolling flat colour for ages, and while a couple of these were really interesting, especially the snow area with it's really pretty atmosphere, the quantity of them ended up being a bit much in the end, with some being far worse than others. There were also a couple of frustrating elements that made me completely dread the possibility of having to go through it again, particularly the one that was a huge maze of islands connected by teleporter squares, without enough visual information to be able to differentiate them from one another to the point where you could be aimlessly and frustratedly wandering around for way too long, just hoping that you'd eventually find the way out.

Even with its shortcomings, Yume Nikki is a truly amazing game but also one that I definitely understand not being for everyone. While I felt that the atmosphere and general vibes carried the game to such a high degree that its intentionally barebones gameplay ended up working almost perfectly fine for me, I also could definitely see the perspective in which it doesn't and it just all feels like aimless wandering without any substance. I really enjoyed my time with Yume Nikki, all the small narratives and goals that I set myself, all the weird and wonderful dreamscapes to explore, and especially the way that the naturally increasing familiarity that a player gets with this game as they play ends up changing the atmosphere and tone in such a dramatic way to the point where what first felt like an uncomfortable foray into unfamiliar territory ended up being a thorough exploration of a surreal, beautiful world that you wanted to discover all the little details of. Really just, fantastic stuff, go play it

9/10
